title: Berryfolia
author: Berryfolia
content: The future of bitcoin is still not a stable one,there’s a lot of controversies as to,as it has many regulation issues.Even the original founder of bitcoin,in fact, has left his position as it was headed in a direction that he did not intend(debatable).The average consumer is not yet comfortable with the idea,or understand,the concept of bitcoin or any cryptocurrency.In my opinion,cryptocurrency will be used in the (far) future as a secure way to transfer money,if it is endorsed by certain regulatory body.It will largely remain to the discretion of the buyer/seller,how they would like to proceed with bitcoin,for the time being.The first person to sell their home for bitcoin already happened in Alberta,Canada who sold his home for the equivalent of $405,000 worth of bitcoin(which was worth much less then),do keep in mind that this was like years ago when 1bitcoin was worth $70,whereas to now 1bitcoin is worth approx.$70,000.If cryptocurrency does not blow up in our face,then i think there would be a cryptocurrency for real estate,but it will be something other than bitcoin and something that a governing body would launch.

comments.author: Fiatless
comments.body: Quote from: Berryfolia on March 24, 2025, 03:01:03 PMThe first person to sell their home for bitcoin already happened in Alberta,Canada who sold his home for the equivalent of $405,000 worth of bitcoin(which was worth much less then),do keep in mind that this was like years ago when 1bitcoin was worth $70,whereas to now 1bitcoin is worth approx.$70,000.If cryptocurrency does not blow up in our face,then i think there would be a cryptocurrency for real estate,but it will be something other than bitcoin and something that a governing body would launch.Before anyone should consider selling his house to invest in Bitcoin, he should know the risk that is involved. He should have a well designed plan to avoid regrets. It wouldn't be a bad idea to sell property to invest in Bitcoin if the individual has more than one. Real estate is a good investment, so it will be better to diversify investment than to depend only on one asset. The Canadian that sold his property to buy Bitcoin was brave, he deserves all the profits.

comments.author: uneng
comments.body: Bitcoin is self sufficient, what means it doesn't need centralized systems to work. On the other hand, regulatory bodies don't want a decentralized system like that to take place, because they want to make sure to be in charge of the system, controlling and watching it in real time. Therefore, it's unlikely regulators adopt Bitcoin. For them, it's more interesting to just copy Bitcoin's technology, creating their own cryptocurrencies on the sequence.Regards real estate, I would really enjoy if it was possible to buy and sell properties through BTC currency. Actually, I've already tried, but real estate agents and houses' owners weren't interested on the proposal. They demand to make the deal in fiat currency.Bitcoin is too volatile and risky for most people, so you can conclude a large transaction involving real estate is definitely out of their radar.

comments.author: Frankolala
comments.body: Anything created by the government can easily be manipulated. Bitcoin is decentralized and is not censorship. Bitcoin has come to stay and still remain the best currency that man has ever created.Quotewhereas to now 1bitcoin is worth approx.$70,000.If cryptocurrency does not blow up in our face,then i think there would be a cryptocurrency for real estate,but it will be something other than bitcoin and something that a governing body would launch1btc is currently $88,320 as I am typing this post. It's not only bitcoin that you can use to buy an estate, you can use some altcoins depending on the agreement with yiu and the seller. I believe the US will accept all those altcoins that Trump added to US bitcoin reserve to buy any property in the US.

comments.author: cryptoaddictchie
comments.body: Quote from: Berryfolia on March 24, 2025, 03:01:03 PM i think there would be a cryptocurrency for real estate,but it will be something other than bitcoin and something that a governing body would launch.You mean coins meant for this? I think theres plenty who plan and wanted that to exist but still fails. So I guess using the common cryptocurrency is better than make a new coin for real statw which no one would buy to exchange or use for selling properties. Why to use that if we have solid coin such as bitcoin that has been trusted by most and many users worldwide.

comments.author: avikz
comments.body: Quote from: Berryfolia on March 24, 2025, 03:01:03 PMThe future of bitcoin is still not a stable one,there’s a lot of controversies as to,as it has many regulation issues.Even the original founder of bitcoin,in fact, has left his position as it was headed in a direction that he did not intend(debatable).The average consumer is not yet comfortable with the idea,or understand,the concept of bitcoin or any cryptocurrency.And it will never be stable. Bitcoin is an attractive investment vehicle because the price is always fluctuating and has a huge upside potential. The concept will be known to the population slowly but surely. It is still comparatively a new currency. QuoteIn my opinion,cryptocurrency will be used in the (far) future as a secure way to transfer money,if it is endorsed by certain regulatory body.It will largely remain to the discretion of the buyer/seller,how they would like to proceed with bitcoin,for the time being.It is already being used as a currency system. However I understand that unclear regulatory framework is discouraging a lot of people to get into crypto currency. I am sure a lot more clarity will be available with time. QuoteThe first person to sell their home for bitcoin already happened in Alberta,Canada who sold his home for the equivalent of $405,000 worth of bitcoin(which was worth much less then),do keep in mind that this was like years ago when 1bitcoin was worth $70,whereas to now 1bitcoin is worth approx.$70,000.If cryptocurrency does not blow up in our face,then i think there would be a cryptocurrency for real estate,but it will be something other than bitcoin and something that a governing body would launch.I know a similar story for ETH. A person sold his home to buy ETH at $3. He is a multi millionaire today. Some people have taken calculated risk and came out as a winner at the end. But the experience may not be same for everyone. So I would say it's a move where a lot of factors need to be considered. I am not sure what do you mean by the crypto currency for real estate. But I can tell you that the market doesn't need another cryptocurrency specific to real estate.

Bitcoin is not abandoned by Satoshi but bitcoin is inherited and you have to underline that. 1 bitcoin is not $70K and you are again saying baseless bullshit.

comments.author: Orpichukwu
comments.body: Bitcoin was created, and other cryptocurrencies followed – both the ones that are there to serve real purposes and the ones which are there just for the sake of it or to exploit. Not every project or something needs to have their own coin unless their need for the coin is to generate wealth and revenue for themselves. I don't buy the idea of real estate having a token which will be used to buy properties; it will be worthless from the beginning. It will appear like something which will be promising over time, but it will all be an investment gone wrong, as no one will actually want to make use of it.

comments.author: cxtreenal
comments.body: As there is no regulatory body for Bitcoin, you are still writing on its forums and I am also getting a chance to read and waiting for a more higher value. Your assumption seems to be in confusion. If you consider Bitcoin as a store of value rather than just a cryptocurrency, your average judgment may be thrown into the deep end and you may be encouraged to invest more.

comments.author: aoluain
comments.created_time: March 24, 2025, 06:03:18 PMLast edit: March 24, 2025, 06:15:26 PM by aoluain
comments.body: Wow - a lot to pick apart with the OPQuote from: Berryfolia on March 24, 2025, 03:01:03 PMThe future of bitcoin is still not a stable oneWhat is a stable alternative?Do we necessarily want Bitcoin to be stable?Quote from: Berryfolia on March 24, 2025, 03:01:03 PMthere’s a lot of controversies as to,as it has many regulation issues.Most of us here dont necessarily care for regulation, Bitcoin is decentralised and by that goesagainst regulation. Anyway Bitcoin itself cannot be regulated, how you convert FIAT to and fromBitcoin can be.Quote from: Berryfolia on March 24, 2025, 03:01:03 PMEven the original founder of bitcoin,in fact, has left his position as it was headed in a direction that he did not intend(debatable).Incorrect - Satoshi was fearful that the authorities would come down hard on HIM/HER/THEM and so took the correct decision to disappear. Read Satoshi's farewell, Satoshi was very happy with the direction Bitcoin was headed.Quote from: satoshi on December 11, 2010, 11:39:16 PMIt would have been nice to get this attention in any other context.  WikiLeaks has kicked the hornet's nest, and the swarm is headed towards us.Quote from: satoshiI've moved on to other things.  It's in good hands with Gavin and everyone.I do hope your BitcoinJ continues to be developed into an alternative client.  It gives Java devs something to work on, and it's easier with a simpler foundation that doesn't have to do everything.  It'll get critical mass when impatient new users can get started using it while the other one is still downloading the block chain.Quote from: Berryfolia on March 24, 2025, 03:01:03 PMThe average consumer is not yet comfortable with the idea,or understand,the concept of bitcoin or any cryptocurrency.Contrary to what some people think, Bitcoin will not become the one world currency, not everyonesaves money, not everyone thinks of their financial future, not everyone is financially educated.Quote from: Berryfolia on March 24, 2025, 03:01:03 PMIn my opinion,cryptocurrency will be used in the (far) future as a secure way to transfer money,if it is endorsed by certain regulatory body.It will largely remain to the discretion of the buyer/seller,how they would like to proceed with bitcoin,for the time being.Cryptocurrency is different to Bitcoin, Crypto is largely regarded as all other blockchain projects.Bitcoin currently is very secure for transferring money. The weakest link is at both human ends,the sender and receiver and how they decide to store their Bitcoin. The Bitcoin network has never been hacked!

comments.author: OgNasty
comments.body: The immediate future for Bitcoin and real estate seems like it will be banks using Bitcoin as collateral for loans at attractive rates. No more having to beg the bank for a loan and jump through hoops to get a good rate. Just deposit some BTC and boom, you have a credit line for houses or whatever else you need.

That would expose both parties to unnecessary litigation and the buyer could face more risk. Not to mention, it's a huge amount of money so it's completely reasonable for them to refuse your request.

comments.author: TheUltraElite
comments.body: Keeping the unending talk about Satoshi aside, I think the decentralization theme of bitcoin has been one of the core strengths.Regulation depends on the government policies, which are still new and hatching in most countries. If you are scared of them dont come into bitcoin but those who take the risk of getting into bitcoin will surely profit.When it comes to leaving a job or selling a house for bitcoin, I am always against it. A house has a purpose and is stable investment over the years. Bitcoin may take time to be so easily spent on groceries like fiat that it may take decades to reach. On the contrary that house will have served its purpose by that time.So if you want to invest in bitcoin buy it at the low and dont think about selling houses for it. You dont need to grab 1BTC you can and should only buy fractions which eventually add up every time the market goes down.
